description:
Volvox carteri f. nagariensis is a species of green algae belonging to the genus Volvox. It is a multicellular, colonial organism that exhibits a spherical or ellipsoidal shape, with thousands of individual cells arranged on the surface of a gelatinous matrix.

The individual cells of Volvox carteri f. nagariensis are small, biflagellate, and embedded within the colonial structure. They are capable of photosynthesis and contribute to the overall metabolic processes of the colony.

This species is characterized by the presence of specialized reproductive cells, known as gonidia, which are larger than the somatic cells and responsible for the asexual reproduction of the colony. The gonidia undergo a series of cell divisions within the parent colony, ultimately forming a new daughter colony that is released upon the disintegration of the parent.

Volvox carteri f. nagariensis is found in freshwater habitats, such as ponds, lakes, and slow-moving streams, and is known for its unique developmental patterns and the complexity of its colonial organization, which has made it a valuable model organism for the study of multicellular evolution and developmental biology.
